1106566761862692864.text: And if lots of people keep asking “how is this different from Y?” then you know what the first thing is that you have to explain!

1106566259485728768.text: It can be hard to think of or discover all the things related to what you’re doing, especially if it is literature that doesn’t speak to your actual research question. Talking to people about your work helps you discover that.

1106565812326825984.text: Because you will eventually write papers or apply for grants about things. And those reviewers will ask “how does this relate to X?” And you can’t be successful and respond “X is not what I’m studying”. It’s is your job to compare, contrast, and explain the relationship.

1106565492351787009.text: Of course it’s useful to read related things.  But earlier in my career I would have been like “why don’t people get the precise question I asked about? I was so clear!” And the answer is usually (1) they do understand and (2) they are helping even if they don’t.

999789613580464128.text:
For the person who can't take the hint: use the mute button on air.
In person, "We're going to move on from that now."
(loudly, if necessary) "I'm the one speaking up here / leading this discussion." (use sparingly, but don't hesitate when necessary) 

Have more? Plz share!
5/5

999789474354810880.text:
For the rambler/long talker: Interrupt with "Let me stop you there and summarize your question"

For the person who really wants to argue an off topic point: "I hear your concern, but I want to bring this back around to our main topic."
4/5

999789409410183168.text:
You don't have to pander to people asking questions or raising issues UNLESS it drives the conversation and benefits everyone else.

My tips (and journalist friends will have much better advice):
3/5

999789364916842496.text:
If someone goes off on a tangent, offers a soliloquy, gets in an argument with another student/question asker, it is your job to shut that nonsense down! No one is there for that!

Doing this respectfully & kindly (& ideally so they don't notice), is a hard skill to master! 2/5

999789189746036736.text:
Advice I received for hosting live radio that has helped in all my talks and teaching: Your responsibility is to the *audience*!

Obv, that applies to your content, but it's super important when managing questions & discussion. 1/5

933061373583650818.text:
Say your cable company / ISP has a crappy video service they want to compete with Netflix. 
They could TOTALLY BLOCK YOU from accessing Netflix & force you to use their inferior product. 
That's what will happen if @AjitPaiFCC repeals #NetNeutrality.

933061070272548865.text:
The "heavy handed" Obama-era rules that @AjitPaiFCC criticizes say just this:
-No blocking content
-No slowing certain websites
 #NetNeutrality

933060088079749120.text:
Do you want to run an online business? 
Then pay a fee to EVERY US-BASED ISP if you want your site seen. Otherwise it will run slow or be blocked altogether. 
That's what will happen if @AjitPaiFCC repeals #NetNeutrality.

933059632255459328.text:
Do you trust your ISP will not filter online content they object to? 
What if they block sites where you can complain about them? Or block political content they dislike?
That's what will happen if @AjitPaiFCC repeals #NetNeutrality.

933059225647009792.text:
Do you want your internet to be limited to bundles of sites you pay to access?
This is what's happened in Portugal w/o #NetNeutrality. 
That's what will happen if @AjitPaiFCC repeals #NetNeutrality in the US.pic.twitter.com/8mVAVjZN7l

933058647881633792.text:
Do you want your cable company deciding what websites you can see and which you can't? 
That's what will happen if @AjitPaiFCC repeals #NetNeutrality.

864296739938947072.text: end/ In sum, classified information is EXTREMELY SERIOUS BUSINESS. It's not something that anyone who knows better would just let slip by.

864296473759973377.text: 9/ And had to do more training. I'm lucky nothing worse happened. That was all for just printing something on the wrong printer!

864296197162500096.text: 8/ I didn't know better, but I got very stern talkings to by a whole lot of senior people in State and at CIA (our offices were together)

864296030950633474.text: 7/ You are not allowed to just bring that home! So there was no security risk, but when my bosses found out what happened, it was bad.

864295888893743105.text: 6/ If a document is printed from a classified printer, it's classified, even if the contents are unclassified. My doc was now Top Secret.

864295741057052672.text: 5/ It had been printed on a classified printer. There are separate printers/copiers/etc for class/unclass documents.
